This film seems pedigreed for the Academy: a story about the British royals, a period piece, encompassing WWII, a character with a physical ailment he must overcome, class confrontations and an unlikely friendship. And it really happened. Yet thanks to a marvelous cast, witty and heartfelt writing, and sure-handed direction this film emerges as one of 2010's very best films. The movie tips us to its brilliance in the opening scene--a masterfully tense sequence where the stammering Duke of York must make his first speech to the British Empire in 1925 on the radio, which consisted of approximately a fourth of the world's population. The fear perfectly conveyed on Colin Firth's face, the fear and sympathy pouring out of Helena Bonham Carter's loving wife, all aided by director Tom Hooper's gliding camera and crisp editing, results in a heartbreaking moment of terror and hesitation. Firth has always been good, but delivers a true Oscar-worthy performance as the stuttering prince who would be king and lead his country through a key time in Europe's history. Bonham Carter is so warm and caring she reminds us why millions fell in love with the woman who would go on to their Queen Mother. Geoffrey Rush brings a great dose of fun and laughs as the teacher who must help this man overcome his disability, by any means necessary. The film also features wonderful casting flourishes in smaller roles: Guy Pearce as the self-absorbed and cowardly Prince Edward VIII, Michael Gambon as a bluff King George V, Timothy Spall as a wry Winston Churchill, Derek Jacobi as a flustered archbishop. It's a magnificent cast, with not one bad performance. The film is also a triumph of style, with divine period details and cinematography, as Hooper shot this with big lenses that make interiors look overbearing, long and narrow, visually representing the King's psychosis involving his closing throat and fear of inadequacy. Thanks to everyone involved, this is a fascinating, engrossing, emotional and inspiring true story that is worth seeking out for your immense viewing pleasure

The King's Speech follows Prince Albert (Colin Firth) who has a terrible stammer and sees an Australian therapist Lionel Logue (Geoffrey Rush). The two men become best friends and, after Edward VIII's (Guy Pearce) abdication, the new king needs Lionel to help prepare for his famous WWII speech. What I especially love about the movie is that it focuses more on the bond between the two and how they work off each other during their lessons. In fact, during acting class in college, I incorporated some of Lionel's techniques in preparation for reciting lines or getting in character. As for the production design, instead of shooting in a replicated sound stage like so many period dramas, they use constricted Victorian Pullens rooms in Southwark. Aside from invoking the rustic Anglo-Saxon authenticity, it matches Bertie's struggles and insecurities. However, during the radio speech, King George VI becomes more comfortable showing his voice, so the sets are more spacious and less claustrophobic. On top of that, combining the tight and broad rooms together really adds to the friendship between Bertie and Lionel. When they first meet, the teal walls are constrictive, but by the end it's much wider. So, The King's Speech is as much about the main character overcoming his disability as much as the friendship of the King and his tutor.

I really, really didn't like this film and although it was more watchable than the 4 hours long Dances with Wolves (1990) which I also watched today I may enjoy that film more.

Prince Albert, Colin Firth, who will go on to become King George V, suffers from stammering which he will have to cure as the Royal family takes more of a public role in the lives of the â~commoners'. His supportive wife Elizabeth, Helena Bonham Carter, enlists Australian speech therapist Lionel Logue, Geoffrey Rush, to treat her husband but his unorthodox methods and frank conversational skills put him at odds with "Bertie." When Albert's brother King Edward VIII, Guy Pearce, abdicates from the throne in order to marry Wallis Simpson, Eve Best, who is portrayed as villainous figure here, he must ascend to the position himself. Logue and Bertie become friends as they work to remove his speech impediment and keep the British people happy.

Possibly the most interesting part of the film, to me, was Logue's interest in acting. We see him attend an audition at which he is looked down upon by the theatre members but he valiantly defends his dramatic background even as the disappointment is evident in his eyes. We also see him reenact scenes from various plays to his sons and we understand that these activities bring them all enjoyment. Obviously actors are not doing the most important job in the world but the rejection that they face as they are required to put themselves out there for their job is relatable to all. As a New Zealander the relative condemnation he faces from British nationals who believe themselves to be superior, they are most definitely not, also struck a chord with me. I wanted more focus on this sort of story in the film as seeing people who truly love what they do not give up despite considerable obstacles is wonderful and the few scenes that focus on this were more exciting than anything else in the film.

The treatment of royalty, as in The Queen (2006), made my blood boil as their haughtiness and poor treatment of those around them despite not being anything special is seen as entertaining and right by the screenwriters. Talk of etiquette and disrespect is peppered throughout as Edward and Wallis, supposedly a prostitute and philanderer according to this film, are seen as traitors to the family. Although the real life figures were truly awful, Nazism is unforgivable, it was not their love or her being divorced that they should be condemned for. All of the obsessing over this sort of thing probably would have had royalists going wild but it left me irked. 

The biggest issue with the film was that I never cared about the main character. He was unsympathetic and dull and Firth's performance did not grab me as it should have for all the acclaim it received. The entire central conceit of the film felt rather silly to me, especially when the film took itself so seriously, to the point that I laughed at moments that were meant to contain dramatic tension. If you can't muster up any real care for the human being that is meant to be the central character of the film then it is not a worthwhile venture.

This is a film that will suit the Masterpiece Theatre crowd but it is inarguable that The Social Network is a better film and concerns a far more timely figure. This is not worth watching, see The Crown television series instead, because it focuses on the wrong person.

Tom Hooper's historical drama The King's Speech (2010) is a fantastic perspective on the real life verbal melees that King George VI suffered with his whole life as he attempts to overcome his speech impediment stammer. Hooper's direction is a gorgeous recreation of wartime Britain from the death of King George V to King George VI. Hooper's style is sleek and fluid, quickly moving from scene to scene to keep you on edge to feel the pressure that the royals were in during the changeover of kings.

Colin Firth is marvelous as the frustrated and distressed monarch King George VI. Firth lends the king a sympathetic persona as you care if this man will rise to the challenge of leading his country into war with Adolf Hitler and Germany through his war speech announcement. The conflict may seem trivial at first, but the fate and morale of England was at stake on his majesty's oratory skills. Firth portrays King George VI as a capable man that lacked the confidence to say what he wanted. Through Firth's remarkable performance we sympathize with a man at odd's with his responsibilities and newfound status. I found Firth's acting gave King George VI a humanistic relatable air in his display of a palpable fury at his own inability to speak clearly. Colin Firth is simply moving in The King's Speech.

Similarly, Geoffrey Rush is hilarious as the king's Australian speech therapist. His patience, kindness, humor, and understanding give the audience an empathetic viewpoint into the trials of nervousness the monarchy underwent during World War II. Rush is so funny, likable, and endearing that you are with him the whole way through The King's Speech. He is a triumphant portal of sensitivity in the film, who you feel an affinity for always.

If I have to spell it out, there are five major Academy Awards handed out each year: (1) Best Picture; (2) Best Director; (3) Best Actor; (4) Best Actress; and (5) either Best Original or Adapted Screenplay. The King's Speech won 4 of those awards, which in itself is no easy feat. Almost nobody would complain at The King's Speech having won Best Director, Best Actor, and Best Original Screenplay. Firth's and Rush's performances were sublime, and Helena Bonham Carter was a strong supporting actress. Why all the complaints then? Most critics of this movie will say because The King's Speech is "Oscar bait," but I don't buy that reasoning. Arguably, every good movie is, in some sense, an Oscar bait, as every good director will try to find new ways to make creative shots and build a storyline that will ultimately be successful. By this standard, the movies There Will Be Blood and No Country for Old Men are also Oscar baits, but hardly anyone complains about them. It seems ridiculous to me to criticize a movie because it was done well. At its core, the work of a director is to be a visual storyteller; accolades like the Academy Awards are simply given to those who succeed at it.

Any discussion about The King's Speech has to start and end with the excellent acting performances of Colin Firth and Geoffrey Rush.  They play such endearing characters and I love everything about their performances, and the relationship formed between their characters.  Even the stuttering, which can be a hard thing to add to an acting role without sounding artificial, was well done.  In fact, after watching the film I was compelled to look up audio recordings of the actual speech delivered by Kind George VI, and Firth really nailed it.  I also loved how they accentuated the intimidating nature of the microphone.  In many ways the villain of this movie is that device and how it will make or break George's reign as King, so they were very clever about making this inanimate object look large and even a bit menacing.  I found the movie extraordinarily heartwarming and was almost brought to tears at one point.  I've never had difficulty speaking in front of people, but I can fully appreciate being overcome with feelings of inadequacy and fear.

At one point I thought this might become a favorite film and I was going to rate it extremely high, but there was something about the climax that left me wanting more.  I realize there's only so much they could do, because they were attempting to be somewhat historically accurate, but I was hoping for some type of cathartic moment where suddenly they were able to address all the root issues and create a dramatic change for the King.  Again, I understand this isn't what really happened, and it probably is not how it ever works when people are dealing with a speech impediment.  Yet for a movie, it needed an added punch to impact me more deeply.  Perhaps if there was some more dramatic scene or montage that showed how his speeches actually impacted his people, that would have given me the extra "something special" I was seeking.  But despite my reservations, the movie did warm my heart and it was brilliantly acted.  I would still recommend it to anyone who's interested.

When it comes to subject choice in movies, one of the most well-explored areas is royalty, which raises the question, do we really need another one? We've been through everything from butlers to monarchs with results varying from good to terrible. However, The King's Speech is not just another royalty flick. It stands tall among the very strongest of its genre through the strength of its script, direction and especially its performers. 

The King's Speech is the story of King George VI, Bertie (Firth) to his friends, and his ascension to the throne after the death of his father (Gambon) and his brother's (Pearce) abdication. The only problem is his stammer. Bertie can barely blurt out a sentence without st-stuttering through every word. In order to overcome this impediment, his wife (Carter) enlists the help of a slightly unorthodox speech therapist, Lionel Logue (Rush). This may seem a thin premise to hang a film on, but the themes explored with admirable confidence are more than enough to fill two hours with. 

The entire cast, bursting at the seams with talent, put in oscar worthy performances, with the fiery yet burdened Colin Firth incredible as the King, the demure yet commanding Helena Bonham Carter as Queen Elizabeth and the inimitable Geoffery Rush as Lionel Logue. Leading the cast is Firth whose entire career is littered with brilliant performances, and he outdoes himself yet again with a beautifully restrained, utterly human performance which you cannot help but feel for. He also pulls off some welcome flashes of humour and brings on the fire and brimstone with fantastic conviction, all the while maintaining a perfectly imperfect stammer which pervades, but never gets in the way of, his towering performance. And the chemistry which he finds with his co-star Geoffery Rush makes for one of the more believeable and exciting male partnerships in years. Rush's own performance matches Firth's in terms of subtlety and nuance as well as the same level of perfectly judged restraint, yet the two never seem at odds, finding a rhythm with each other in their slowly building friendship which is at times flat out hilarious and at others brilliantly intense. It is an breathtaking display of two top-class actors working seamlessly together. Helena Bonham Carter plays the ever-supporting Queen Elizabeth who, in the hands of a lesser actor, could have turned into a stereotype but is instead a strong, quiet character in her own right. She is able to command a room with a look but also able to guide her husband through some of the hardest days he has had to face, showing a beautiful light and shade in an entirely selfless performance. Guy Pearce, though lacking a lot of the screentime his co-stars are given, makes and incredible impact in every one of his scenes. His slimy Edward is the unofficial villain of the piece and he manages to be spitefully real at every turn. It's one of his finest performances and, in comparison to his co-stars, he barely graces the screen. 

The script which all these performances hang off is a thing of beauty. It manages to combine reality and creativity seamlessly with never a moment devoid of the reality it deserves whilst never missing out on an opportunity for the humour and intensity which the film is strewn with. Unexpectedly, the film also quite a bit of abbraisive language, but the context which it's in means that even the most sensitive of viewers won't be turned off. But its greatest achievement is the very real characters it helps create and the relationships it helps to extend. 

Tom Hooper nails the direction, despite the tremendous leap forward in terms of content and responsibility. His biggest venture before his latest is 2009's The Damned United, so it's quite a step up in exposure, yet he never seems to show it, taking bold risks with confidence. His use of fisheye lenses is reminiscent of Kubrick and he uses the effect sparingly and effectively. He also pushes the rule of thirds to the extreme, making for some eye-catching shots which are either genius or annoying depending on your point of view. I'm for 'genius' by the way. 

But the greatest part of the movie is the tangible connection created between characters and audience and the pounding in your chest when Bertie takes the microphone or Lionel oversteps his bounds on a morning walk as every part of the film works together in a beautifully restrained piece of filmmaking.

It seems as though historical films never get all of the details right about the actual events. Look up the Wikipedia article on any movie based on a real event and you'll find a section entitled "historical accuracy" devoted to tearing apart the work for any liberties taken. Sometimes, these creative choices can be beneficial to the plot. In The Sound of Music, it is very satisfying to watch the Von Trapps climb over the Alps at the end, and it makes for a much better conclusion than watching them board a train as the actual family did in real life. Some changes in these films, however, are taken to appease the filmmaker's agenda, such as when Michael Bay chose to show the Japanese bombing the hospital in Pearl Harbor. Although I feel that changes such as this can be harmful to both the art of film and our society in general, I don't believe that we should discard all historical movies just because of their inaccuracies. No matter what care is put into the filmmaking process, there is no way that all of the facts of an event can be crammed into a two-hour window. With that in mind, I recommend that we sit back and watch these films, overlooking the minor differences between the real story and the fiction, and look instead at the movie's deeper meaning. With that in mind, let's dive into The King's Speech.

In this 2010 Tom Hooper drama, Colin Firth plays Prince Albert, the Duke of York and the son of King George V. From a very young age, Albert has had a strong stutter in his speech, something that both he as his wife Elizabeth, played by Helena Bonham Carter, are concerned about because of the great amount of public speaking that he has to do. After looking to a number of different sources for a cure, Elizabeth finds a man named Lionel Logue, an Australian speech therapist played by Geoffrey Rush. After an unpleasant first session that ends up yielding Mr. Miyagi-style results, Albert agrees to have regular sessions with Logue, whose methods have a profound effect on the Prince. The two soon become good friends, and Albert looks to Logue as someone to confide in about his personal problems as well as his stammer. As Albert's speech improves, other ares of his life spiral downward as his father's health becomes worse in his old age and his disgraceful brother, David, plans to accede to the throne. Albert approaches a time in his life that will require him to make many hard decisions if he wants to protect both his country and his family's image from his brother's recklessness.

Colin Firth won the Academy Award for Best Actor because of this movie, and I personally believe that he was completely deserving of the accolade. Firth's portrayal of the stammering Prince Albert is both convincing and heartbreaking, showing both the difficulties of being a public figure with a speech impediment and the cause of his insecurities. Firth also does a great job showing a character who gradually improves over the course of the film. Although I've never had any sort of speech problem, I can relate to the character of Albert as someone who spends a great deal practicing a certain craft. The scenes of Albert's early sessions that depict him struggling through speech exercises reminded me of the first few years of my guitar playing, in which I had great difficulty with most passages and exercises that I attempted. I also appreciated how he is still not the perfect speaker at the film's conclusion. Practicing your craft takes many years, and it's something that can always be improved upon. I believe that anyone who is involved with an occupation or hobby that requires great practice can relate to Albert's struggle, and Firth's performance is very inspiring to all who are hoping to become skilled individuals.

The King's Speech was also very unique in the direction and feel of the movie. I've noticed over the past several years that there are more and more films being nominated by the Academy with incredibly dark subject material. The King's Speech is, essentially, a very basic tale about a man overcoming the obstacles in his life and taking hold of his responsibilities. There's no uncomfortable scene of domestic abuse, no gratuitous nudity (or any nudity at all, for that matter), and no bizarre monologues about milkshakes. All of these qualities can still be present in a great film and can be used to enhance the film, but none of them were necessary in The King's Speech. Despite the simplicity of the story, the stylish and masterful direction of the film keeps the plot from feeling stale. There isn't a single wasted scene in the film; every frame is devoted to the lives and struggles of Albert, Logue, and Elizabeth.

Another thing that I found interesting about this film is that it was rated R for language. However, there were only two scenes that used the sort of language that warrants an R rating, while most R-rated Oscar-nominated dramas contain harsh language throughout the entire running time. This means that the filmmakers found these two scenes so necessary to the plot that they were willing to suffer with the R-rating, a risky choice, as it  is well-known that R-rated films generally don't do as well at the box office as PG and PG-13 flicks.

As I stated at the beginning of this review, the film isn't completely accurate to the actual historical account of Prince Albert and Logue. The entire timeline of the film is shifted about ten years after the two began their sessions so that Hooper could show both Prince Albert's struggle with his speech and with his brother, as well as the Duke's response to Hitler's conquest of Europe. It is also well-known that it took a much shorter amount of time for Albert's speech to improve than the film suggests, as he was praised for his speech at the Australian Parliament in Canberra in 1927, only seven months after his first session with Logue. However, I believe that these minor changes do not tarnish the overall significance of the film. Despite the deviations between the story presented here and the actual tale of the Duke of York, we are still given a film that enriches our understanding of Prince Albert and that can encourage us to overcome our own shortcomings, as well. This film is solidly on what I'll call the "Von Trapp Mountain-Climbing" side of the historical inaccuracy line, and it's a culturally significant work that is both educational and inspiring.

2010's recipient of the Academy Award for Best Picture, Tom Hooper's 'The King's Speech,' is an understated film that explores many themes including family, friendship and pride. Using the transfer of power in pre-World War II Great Britain as a backdrop, 'Speech' examines the metamorphosis of George VI as he grows into his role as king following a controversial episode within his royal family, and the lengths he goes to to eradicate an embarrassing stutter in an age of radio. Colin Firth, who won an Oscar for his performance as the aforementioned king, does a respectable job and makes audiences feel for his character due to the issues he deals with, stutter and all. Of course, the focal point of 'Speech' is the king's relationship with Australian speech therapist Lionel Logue (Geoffrey Rush), which undergoes an evolution of its own as the two spar with one another throughout the film. Other acting performances can be considered standouts, including Helena Bonham Carter as Queen Elizabeth (the older one, not the current one). Also admirable is the cinematography - for such a simple film that focuses on content over visual impressiveness, the camera work is very high quality. And then there's the title itself - 'The King's Speech' has a double meaning in that while the film is of course focused on George VI's speech impediment, it also notes the power conveyed in his most trying hour - a speech to the British empire announcing it was at war with Nazi Germany. Hoopers low-budget The King's Speech' may not seem to be the most popular film of the last few years, but history should remember it as a landmark achievement years from now.

The King's Speech tells the story of King George VI (Colin Firth) overcoming his stutter in order to deliver a speech to the United Kingdom declaring they were going to war with Germany in 1939. To do this he has to work with vocal coach and therapist Lionel Logue (Geoffrey Rush) who pushes George's voice to do what he feels is impossible.

Things I Liked:

Colin Firth. Firth plays George and does so remarkably. You really feel as though he himself is fighting the stutter. He does all of the vocal work so naturally and plays the character in a very simple and elegant way. He really carries the film well and gives a remarkable performance.

Geoffrey Rush. Rush plays Lionel Logue, George's vocal coach, in a way that reminds you how good Rush really is. He has a great sense of patience, charm, cleverness, and you again don't get the sense that he is playing a character. He seems so natural and it really makes the work Firth does better with their chemistry.

The Tone. The film has a some incredibly serious moments but it also has moments of humor that really fit in with the film and make the film better as a result. The movie never gets to the point where you feel it could fall apart and it keeps the movie moving forward, which is good because movies about personal growth can be very stagnant.

Things I Didn't Like:

So the movie has moments that drag and make it feel incredibly long. The plot itself isn't the most interesting overall to begin with so there are points where you really want the movie to move forward when it simply won't.

Overall. Overall the performances carry this movie. Firth and Rush shine and make the movie with their chemistry and their work with the rest of the supporting players. The plot is very simple and the story doesn't go too far in the end so this causes the movie to drag in places and feel longer than in needs to be but the actors really make the movie watchable and the tone of the film uses humor to keep the action much more interesting. It's a very well crafted and well performed movie.

Be forewarned: since this film has already been out for almost three years, this will be a spoiler review, dissecting specific elements of its content.  

        First off, The King's Speech really is one of those films you truly appreciate on a second viewing.  Its impeccable acting, witty writing, and thematic material strongly shine through when you're viewing it for further analysis.  Now, I had a difficult time accepting the film as "Best Picture Winner" the first time around because although its story and acting definitely sparked its quality, it wasn't the heavily-hyped movie I fully expected.  However, this time around, as I watched the film, I could spot so many elements that indicated its overall terrific quality in the end.  So, where do we start?  

        Firstly, its most noticeably excellent aspect is the acting as Colin Firth and Geoffrey Rush convey their respective characters exceptionally.  Colin Firth's performance as a flawed, stammering member of royalty caused me to respect the actor that much more.  As his struggle progressed, I could clearly witness the frustration and hopelessness on his face as "Bertie" (Colin Firth) attempted to cite plays and various speeches.  His portrayal of a man with a speech impediment was incredibly authentic, and the way he constantly faltered in his conversations and addresses ultimately led to an unforgettable performance that was rightfully granted an Oscar.  Then, there was Geoffrey Rush (Lionel) who took on the role of a charming and clever "common man."  

         In this case, The King's Speech was also able to include astonishingly colorful, distinctive, and likable characters that you simply couldn't cease rooting for.  At first, it might've seemed as if Bertie was yet another wealthy, spoiled jerk, but the relationship between Lionel and this man of royalty essentially commenced in such realistic and believable fashion.  Their argumentative and stubborn relationship proceeds throughout the whole film where at one moment, Bertie feels that he's terribly close to his goal, but then something completely unexpected occurs and the realization of where he still remains leads into another struggle with his mentor.  Once the story concludes, not only is Bertie's family, mentor, and fellow colleagues proud of his accomplishment(s), but the audience can't help but crack a wide smile as well.  What surely causes such a scene is the film's wonderful build-up through its tremendous ability of characters and story development. 

          As I've previously mentioned, the script is extraordinarily witty and enthralling.  "Do you know any jokes?"  "...Timing isn't my strong suit."  Those two lines, alone, showcase just how pleasant the dialogue can be.  His response is a joke, in and of itself, along with its delayed timing.  In terms of its story and strong, resonant themes, the movie is highly inspirational as well.  The fact that he has a severe speech impediment and is expected to speak in front of millions of people could be one of the scariest activities to partake in, but this shows the viewers that while you're desperately trying to overcome your fears, it basically can't be that bad for there's always someone dealing with something far worse.  Courage is a monumental feat everyone must, with numerous challenges/obstacles, obtain.  This element certainly resonated with me because I, along with many other people, possess (or, at least, once possessed) fears of public speaking to the point of anxiety. 
 
         In addition, there are several, if not more, other themes throughout, such as the questioning of love/marriage vs. duty.  You have Bertie's brother, David, form issues with Parliament and his process of becoming king as he decides to marry a twice-divorced woman by the name of Wallis Simpson, and it's this struggle that continues where David has to permanently choose between his wife and love or the throne itself, and in the end, he sacrifices his duty as a royal member in order to pursue his romantic relationship with his one true love.  Then, there's another fascinating scene where Bertie's two daughters first sight him in his royal clothing, and for a moment, they're bent on approaching him to hug and kiss, but in a split second, they're now hesitant.  Instead, they decide to bow and address their own father as the king, and you see this distance between the daughters and their father as the greatest representation of how far one must go in pursuing their careers- their own duties- if it means compromising extremely significant relationships in the meantime.  

           Another special triumph of the film is its historical accuracy.  You're informed of the coming war as Hitler's rise progresses throughout the story until finally, it all leads to a climax and interconnects with Bertie's arc, requiring him to deliver a speech and conclusively address this current crisis.  You also see important figures like Winston Churchill and Queen Elizabeth appear during the movie's duration.  Now, I'm not a history buff or anything, but from what I've learned of it, the film did justice to Britain's history.

          The King's Speech also contains a great level of authenticity and realism that's usually unseen in inspirational and motivational films.  The movie tries hard to tone down the cheesiness, and it does it fairly well.  For example, instead of going the "typical Hollywood" route and have Bertie deliver the speech perfectly at the end- of course depicting his final step in the struggle- he still continues the speech by occasionally stammering or pausing between words, and this largely contributes to the film's overall realism and believability.  In fact, there's a surely grand scene towards the end when Bertie is difficultly delivering his motivational speech; while he's struggling with one gigantic issue (his speech impediment), there's another colossal issue with Britain being on the brink of war, and this is followed with amazing shots of the hard times Britain is about to face with soldiers readying themselves and troubled England awaiting the war while a strong, epic soundtrack complements it.    

          Finally, I'd like to take a minute to mention the cinematography as well.  There's an interesting shot later in the film where Bertie is walking away from Lionel due to a disagreement, and as Bertie walks towards the screen, Lionel can be seen in the back with the fog of the park slowly fading his figure with the camera telling its audience that this soon-to-be king is leaving his one friend behind.  Afterwards, proceeding the scene of Bertie's address to his country, Bertie is seen preparing for the speech in the small room where he'll be speaking, and it shows an extreme close-up of his face as if to show the excessive amount of pressure on him.  It even appears like he can't breathe with the small space he's allowed.  There were several other intriguing shots such as these throughout the film.  There's just so much to say about The King's Speech, but after all's been said and done, although it's a tad predictable, it's still a wondrously-crafted film that definitely carries substantial depth.

The Duke Of York hires an unconventional speech therapist when faced with Royal duties in the burgeoning media age to help him with a stammer that prevents his public speaking. The premise behind The King's Speech is a rather dry one and the trailers themselves make it seem to be a cross between The Madness Of King George and Pygmalion, but thanks to some winning performances and an interesting script portraying a behind the scenes window onto recent history it transcends the traditional comedy of manners formula that nearly all British films seem obliged to follow. Colin Firth's portrayal of a man thrust into the public eye by events beyond his control is sublime and it's fascinating to see a snapshot of the man behind a public face completely controlled by propriety and social convention. There's a real warmth in his unlikely friendship with a brewer's son from Australia and the gentle humour and subtle direction makes a very refreshing change from the ADHD firework displays that seem to make up the vast majority of modern cinema. Maybe not the masterpiece its multi-award winning reputation suggests, but a quality cast and sensitive storytelling make for a fine lightly comic and insightful historical character study.
